subject: Draft Musings
event: Well, another NFL draft has come and gone. I liked the new three-day format, with the first round and the second/third being telecast in prime time on Thursday and Friday respectively. The days did not seem quite so endless, and the break between round one and round two allowed for more wheeling and dealing. The first night actually drew higher ratings than the NBA playoff games being broadcast that same night, which just goes to demonstrate the respective popularity of football and basketball in the United States. Who would ever have guessed that what began seventy-five years ago as a bunch of fat old men getting together in a hotel ballroom with a stack of magazines about college football and a lot of index cards would one day become a three-day sporting extravaganza watched in real time by millions of people? And really, under the glitz, it's STILL just a bunch of fat old men with index cards... though with the new format, now at least something actually happens every ten minutes, instead of fifteen as previously. My general impressions. The Seattle Seahawks had the best overall draft. Good picks, and they made some good trades too, including picking up Leon Washington from the Jets. If Leon comes back strong from his broken leg, he'll be a real asset there. The Oakland Raiders also did surprisingly well. (How did that happen? Does someone have Al Davis tied up in a cellar somewhere?) Not only did they snatch Rolando McClain away from my G-Men, damn them, but they traded a late round pick next season for Jason Campbell... who may have been the worst QB in the NFC East last season, but still represents a huge upgrade over JaMarcus "I Complete Forty Per Cent of My Passes" Russell. The Raiders could be dangerous this year; they already had a good defense, and they made it better. With some decent QB play, who knows? Dallas got the highest-rated WR in the draft. Made me grind my teeth. Philadelphia went for quantity, kept trading down for picks. One was Mike Kafka, the QB from my alma mater, Northwestern. I like to see Wildcats make good in the NFL (it happens so seldom), but did it have to be the Iggles? Odds are, some of these picks will turn out to be good, which means Philadelphia likely improved themselves. But I think they will miss Donovan McNabb before the year is out. Eagles fans are excited about Kevin Kolb, based on his performance standing in for McNabb last season, but two games does not a career make. Right now, Philly has the weakest QB in the NFL East, and that will bite them on the ass eventually. Evil Little Bill seemed to have thirty-four picks as well. Thirty-two of them were tight ends. BB must be planning a new offensive scheme; Tom Brady and ten tight ends. And how did my teams do? Glad you asked. The Giants had their usual boring draft. They were slotted in as #15, and that's where they drafted, every round. No moving up, no moving down, no trades, they just sat where they were and picked a player when the pick got round to them. The big excitement was having Mark Bavaro announce one pick for them. The G-Men went into this draft desperately needing linebackers. Especially a middle LB, since they released Antonio Pierce. But the Raiders snatched away Rolando McClain, the LB they were really high on, so they went another way in round one. In round two, everyone expected they would pick Sean Lee or Brandon Spikes, both of whom were still available when they chose, but I guess those guys did not impress them. So as it turned out they did not get a LB until the third day, when they picked Phyllis Diller... er... Phillip Dillard. I found him in my draft magazines, but just barely. Hope to hell he's good. Last year the Giants did not get as many sacks as they had in previous years, true... but even so, the strength of Big Blue's defense has been its defensive ends, a trio relentless pass rushers as good as any in the league -- Osi Umenyiora, Justin Tuck, and Matthias Kiwanuka. So who did they pick in round one? Another pass rusher. A phenom named Jason Pierre-Paul who has supposedly been sensational in all seven of the college games he's started. Also, he can do this: I guess the Giants new defensive coordinator is planning to install a radical new pass rush wherein the ends backflip over the offensive linemen to get to the QB. But seriously, boys and girls... Pierre-Paul does appear to be an amazing athlete, but his lack of actual game experience worries me. My teams have drafted combine heroes before, most recently the Jets with Vernon Ghloston only two years ago, and we know how THAT turned out. In later rounds, the Giants drafted a huge defensive tackle named Joseph (who I hope turns out better than the last huge defensive tackle named Joseph that we drafted), a tall rangy safety, that previously-mentioned linebacker, a "sleeper" linebacker from William & Mary who wasn't even mentioned in any of my draft magazines, an offensive guard who is said to be a real mauler and nasty run-blocker (a bookend to Chris Snee, I hope)... and a punter. I guess that means Jeff Feagles is really going to retire. He is older than I am, after all. I will hate to see Feagles go, though admittedly his punting did fall off badly last year. He's still the best there is at punting from midfield, where he excels at dropping the ball on the opposition's three-yard line. But when the Giants were pinned inside their own twenty and needed a huge booming distance punt to get 'em out of trouble... well, that's where his age showed. If this Dodge kid is half the punter Jeff was, I'll be happy. All in all, a very unglamorous draft. No "sexy" picks. A punter, an offensive lineman, and five defensive players. I doubt any of the draft gurus will rate this draft highly -- but given the way the Giants' defense collapsed last year, it may have been just what we needed. Tom Coughlin hates to give up points, and so do I. (I still wish we had gotten McClain, though). The Jets, as usual, did things differently. They'd already traded away several choices before the draft began, and they traded away a couple of more today, so they ended up with only four choices. And not choices I ever would have expected. Last season Gang Green had the top pass defense in the NFL. It could have been even better with a real stud defensive end sack artist rushing the opposing QB, so I figured that would be what the Jets would go after. But no. Instead they used their first round pick on another cornerback, a kid named Kyle Wilson from Boise State. He looks to be a good one, though. Teamed with Darrelle Revis and Antonio Cromartie, he should give the Jets the best corner trio in the NFL. I don't think Rex wants ANY passes completed against us this year. From now on, he brings nine on every play. But hey, if Wilson is as good as advertised, maybe he'll be able to shut down Wes Welker, who has been killing us every time the Jets play the Patriots. Welker, and the AFC championship game against the Colts, explains why Rex drafted him, I think. Second round the Jets picked a huge Haitian kid named Vladimir Ducasse to play on the offensive line. Guard to start, I guess, maybe eventually right tackle. He's gigantic and very talented, it's said, but raw... but he'll be competing for a starting spot right off, since the Jets have just released Alan Faneca, their big free-agent acquisition from a couple years ago. Faneca is still a hell of a run blocker, and was a major contributor to Gang Green's league-leading rushing attack last season, but he was a liability in pass protection, and gave up way too many sacks. Plugging in a raw kid like Young Vladimir in his place is kind of a risk, even so. In the long run, probably a good move, if Ducasse is as gifted as advertised. In the short run, I hope this doesn't get Mark Sanchez killed. The Jets weren't supposed to pick again until the end of the fourth round... but they traded up into the middle of the fourth to nab Joe McKnight, a running back out of USC. Quick, elusive, shifty, good at catching passes out of the backfield. The choice puzzled the hell out of me, however. "Wait a minute," I said. "We already have a quick, elusive, shifty RB who is good at catching passes out of the backfield. We have Leon Washington. What do we need this Joe guy for?" My question was answered a round later, when the Jets traded Leon Washington and a seventh round pick (their last of the day) to Seattle for their fifth-round pick, so they could choose a huge pile-driver of a fullback named John Connor. (Nicknamed, yes, you guessed it, 'The Terminator'). Kewl. Not many NFL teams use blocking fullbacks any more, but the Giants and Jets are two that do, and I love them. The Jets already have a great blocking fullback in Tony Richardson, but he's almost as old as Jeff Feagles, so I guess John Connor will be his eventual replacement. Must admit, I love the idea of having a Terminator on my team... and there's some suggestion that Connor might be more of a Mike Alstott type, capable of running the ball as well as blocking. If so, I really like this pick. That being said, this Jets draft seems more geared for the long term than for the immediate future. Terminator is a new, younger Tony, but unproven. Vladimir is a new, younger Alan Faneca, only unproven. McKnight is a new, younger Leon Washington, one who hasn't recently suffered a compound fracture of his leg... but still, unproven. The Jets get younger, but do they get better? The only pick that seems likely to provide immediate impact is that first-rounded cornerback from Boise State. And of course the Jets did nothing at all to bolster their pass rush, which remains the most conspicous lack on Rex Ryan's defense. Could it be they still hold out hope for Gholston?

comments.article: Out of Kolbe, Manning, McNabb, and Romo I am gonna predict by the end of next season Kolbe will be thought of as the best QB in the NFC East. I can see it now. Quick accurate 8-10 yard passes all day while DeSean, Maclin, and Celek run after the catch. And now we drafted a lot of defensive players to help chase those other QB's. Things are looking good for the Eagles I think. I pray for revenge against Dallas at the end of the year. They must pay.

I hope you get that vengeance against the C'boys.

Kolb the best QB in the NFL East, though? Have you been drinking that green kool-aid again?

As soon as I saw that Connor was going to the Jets I thought of you George! As a UK football fan, I think you are going to be extremely happy with John Connor. He excels in both run blocking and pass protection, good runner in short yardage situations and can catch the ball out of the backfield if needed. Not to mention, he's a high character guy. Probably my favorite play of his is at the 35 second mark in this video where he blocks one linebacker back into another linebacker: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gwKQmSLObIY

He really is a Terminator!
comments.subject: Connor

comments.article:
I'm disappointed with the Raiders draft, because living in the SF area, it means we don't get to hear everyone complain about Al Davis for the next few months. At least not to the same extent.

I'd have been more excited about the draft as a whole, but my Bears did nothing exciting with what little they had, so, blah. Although I am interested to see what might happen with Lefevour (or however he spells it). He was probably the best QB option out of a school nobody's ever heard of, unless you play obscure ESPN fantasy games.

Now to start working on my fantasy draft lists...
That DE fro, Northwestern could be great, if he comes back from his knee injury.

comments.upictitle: space_geek_ken: river blond black shirt ken
comments.article:
I think that Rex Ryan is betting on Jason Taylor for pass rush, and maybe as someone who can kick Gholston's ass into gear to save his career.

I am cautiously optimistic about Seattle's draft. Washington is coming off of a big injury. LenDale White has a weight problem. I'm not sure who they could've gotten who're better with the picks they gave up...but they got an heir to Walter Jones, and they got a pair of safeties who are immediate upgrades over what we've put on the field.

I am also worried about the loss of pass rush in Seattle, with Daryl Tapp being released (he underperformed his contract) and Petrick Kearney retiring.

I still think Seattle needs to have 10 WRs in their position group, given how many of them have gone down.
comments.subject: Seattle's Draft, Jets

comments.article:
The only thing I didn't like about the Titans' draft was trading off LenWhale.

He lost most of his excess weight and suffered for it. He is in better shape now than he ever was for the Titans and in the right situation could be an excellent primary back. For the Titans he was the "smash" of smash and dash. When he lost his weight to become a real back he wasn't as effective in the role though and lost what carries he was getting to CJ2k.

I hope he succeeds in Seattle, he was always a fun player to watch on and off the field.
comments.subject: Re: Seattle's Draft, Jets

comments.article:
I like that they had a good draft. I've always hated them, but it shouldn't be such a desert island for players to be drafted to. Players shouldn't be UPSET when they're awarded millions to play in Oakland, so to see them improve the way they have is nice to see. I like my sports cyclical, and after a while I get tired of seeing some teams in the cellar, even if I hate them. Every fan should get to see a championship, and if we're lucky, maybe more than one.

The Broncos, for better or for worse, are Josh McDaniels' team now. In an AFC West that appears more open than last year, the Broncos will either make it or sink down to Kansas City-like levels.

I liked my Buccaneers' draft a lot as well. Lots of help on defense and a few WR's to help Josh Freeman out. I think we could win 6-7 games this year, maybe even 8 if we're lucky.

The Jets, of course, are playing all in this year, and it's hard to pick against them. I'm seeing an AFC Championship rematch, except one team peaked a few years ago, and one is hungry and appears to have all the pieces in place. It all hinges on Stafford, and whether he can build on his strong performance in the big game.

I think Kolb will do well, kind of like Aaron Rogers in 2008. But much like Rodgers, solid QB play doesn't necessarily mean wins will follow. Time will tell.

I think the Bears had better look out. The Lions have a solid chance to overtake them this year, methinks.
comments.subject: The Raiders...

comments.article: Don't you mean Sanchez?
comments.subject: Re: The Raiders...

comments.article:
My favorite tweet I read about the Giants' draft was: The Giants are going to the revolutionary 8-1-2 defensive set next season.

Following the draft on Twitter was awesome...got all the picks before they were announced and witnessed a lot of the wheeling and dealing.

Indeed, I was impressed with the Seahawks draft.  The Rams are still the Rams, SF still has Frank Gore but no QB and spotty Defense, and Arizona will be lucky to win 6 games without Warner and the flood of other players that left. If--and it's a big if--Hasselbeck stays healthy, the Seahawks should win the division.  That Okung kid is an immediate upgrade to the anemic O-Line that gave up 44 sacks last season.  Thomas and Tate were outstanding picks and Leon Washington gives us a boost in the backfield.  Speaking of Fullbacks, I agree with you, George.  Seattle's run game really disintegrated when Mack Strong was forced to retire and they were forced to use more single-back sets with 3 or 4 WR's.  I still say Forsett could carry the load, but he'll probably return kicks and punts and be the 3rd down back.  Most teams are going to the running back-by-committee approach, which I find annoying.  I like a good running game; where the featured back gets the rock 25-30 times and pummels the defense into submission.  Anyway, it's looking like a much better year for my team in the upcoming season!

I am an East Carolina University grad and the Giants did end up drafting two of our players. I am a season ticket holder and have seen every snap Linval Joseph and Matt Dodge have played.

In Joseph, you are getting the most dominant lineman we have ever had, and that includes pro bowler Rod Coleman formally of the Falcons. Joseph was one of these huge recruits that originally committed to Florida, but because of scholarship musical chairs ended up with us. And thank the Seven. I have never seen a team successfully shut him down, and we don't play a bunch of sissies. In fact he was a key part of the team that beat #12 Virgina Tech, and I believe #5 West Virginia. He has massive upside.

Dodge is also the best punter we have ever had. His only problem has been consistency. I saw one sports writer mention his pick as questionable because he has a weak leg. Trust me, he confused him with someone else. Matt is like 6'2 and 225 of pure muscle. He is a linebacker who happens to kick. I am serious, he looks like a body builder. Easily the strongest leg I have ever seen, but we know how kicking tryouts go in the NFL, who knows if he actually makes the roster. Cool thing about Dodge, loves contact, I have seen him completely lay out a return man on more than a few occasions.

Just thought you would like a first hand account from one of your fans.
comments.subject: I can tell you a few things about a couple your draftees...

comments.article: As a Boise State fan I have watched Kyle Wilson play for the Broncos the last three and a half years. I don't think you will be disappointed by this kid. Not only is he a talented player, but a class act on and off the field. A tough physical player who in my opinion raises the energy level of everyone around him. Sad to lose him but happy to see him attain his dream.
As a Bronco I can safely say this...with McDaniels around, we sure don't have boring offseasons anymore.

The Giants are pretty good at vetting their picks. JPP is very likely the real deal.

Rex is no dummy where defense is concerned. He must feel certain that the pressure will be there. Maybe Gholston will be used more effectively. No matter, that secondary will be a nightmare to crack.

Even though it was a forgone conclusion from all of the talking heads, I was relieved when my Lions got Suh. He's exactly what they needed. At least, a part of what they needed. If Schwartz had his way, he probably would have drafted an entire Defense this weekend. He seems to know what he's doing (I'm looking at you, Millen), and I'm cautiously optimistic that they could have a good (6-10, I'm not greedy) season.

As for my Steelers, I still haven't forgiven them for giving away Holmes. They drafted ANOTHER running back. Really? But the rest seems like solid line building for the not-so-immediate future.

Hey buddy, don't hate on New England. We aren't getting another superbowl win for at least 20 years. Brady is already past his prime and no longer has an offensive line that can stop everything that comes at him like he did in his first few years. Not to mention, Brady isn't that great himself. He has always been a good quarterback sure, but the only reason he was called "great" was because he had time thanks to his lineman. Sports commentators and Patriots fan in general have given the fellah far too much credit (I don't, but I'm from Western Mass and as such am considered by the Eastern half of the state as Non-Existent) when it really always belonged to the people who would give him as much time as he wanted to make the pass.
Ole Bill made a big mistake grabbing tight ends, he needs a new D-line and a new O-line and just sent us to the land of Football hell. We'll beat Detroit sure, but that's like beating the crippled kid in the 100 yard dash, sure you did it but so did everybody else

As an Iggles fan, I must say that in general, I think most Philadelphians are prepared for a rather poorer year than in years past.  Reid is basically rebuilding the team as thoroughly as he can; for the past ten or twelve years, he's been very loyal to the same players, but a decade with mostly the same people, and they still haven't delivered.  Most people were ready to see McNabb go and are looking more forward to a future powerhouse than a championship this year.  Of course, this doesn't mean that the fans won't still expect a Superbowl out of them every year, even knowing all of this.  But that's just the way we are.

I think you'll be quite happy with Phillip Dillard.  We love us some Suh down here in Nebraska, but the Husker D didn't really start gelling until Dillard got the start.  We're gonna miss him.  The G-Men done good.

This is the first draft weekend in years when I have felt glad to be a Raiders fan.

Incidentally, from comments Tom Cable made in his post-draft press conference, I think the Raiders were going to pick John Connor. They were also interested in Kafka too - he was someone they brought in for a pre-draft visit.

comments.upictitle: Xray Is As Xray Does: spider
comments.article: Mr. X and I are still surprised that someone (for the record, the Panthers) picked up Jimmy Clausen before they drafted Golden Tate (Seahawks). I look forward to putting Claussen on my golf-rules fantasy team since it looks like JaMarcus Russell is facing a life on the bench for the foreseeable future.

Ah, I love the draft. And I agree the new format made it even better. I think having more time between rounds made for MUCH more trades. There also appeared to be very few "wtf??" picks. Only Jacksonville's 1st round pick seemed to turn heads. Oakland on the other hand did a great job. I was tickled when they took a stud LB like McClain, especially since I knew the g-men coveted him so much.

You also might thank Evil Little Bill for the Cowboys being able to move up 4 spots to take Dez Bryant which only cost them swapping 4th round picks with New England. That's very cheap. Evil Bill was reportedly motivated to make the trade as to allow the Cowboys to leapfrog the Ravens and take Dez Bryant. Didn't want to make the powerful AFC Ravens any better!

I was a little surprised with the Jets releasing Alan Faneca but that's turning into a NFL trend. People were saying that with an uncapped season teams would be buying free agents left and right. Hasn't happened. Instead they have released old high priced free agents since there are no salary cap ramifications.
comments.subject: Love me some draft!

comments.article:
Steelers had a nice selection of linemen. I think that Center will work out great, though the Steelers already have one of the best Centers in the NFL.

Also, I loved how they had a Make-A-Wish kid announce their first pick. It's amazing just how much stuff like this the Rooneys do in town.

eh, about the popularity of the NBA, you have a point, but only a little one. Bear in mind, none of the games those nights were critical, and there's another 40 or so left in the playoffs, and at least a whole other month of play.

Check back for the ratings when it's LeBron versus Kobe in Game 7 of the finals.

I am also a huge football fan the Lions are my team. I have been reading your books since the mid 90s. I just thought I would say that the Jets scary me with everthing they have done this offseason, they could be a very dominate team.
comments.subject: draft

comments.article:
The Niners had a great draft, in my opinion. Added 2 dump trucks to the O-line, a younger safety (who is very ticked off at Pete Carroll for skipping him in the first round...watch out Seahawk receivers twice a year). Also picked up UFA RB LeGarrette Blount who was going to go in the first round until he punched someone in a game. Hopefully Coach Sing can rein him in.

I couldn't be happier with the draft. Looking forward to the season. Good luck George!!

I'm more worried about Frank Gore shredding our soft D-Line like the first SF game last season. Carroll should have gone to a 3-4 defense, like practically everyone in Seattle has said for the past 3 seasons.  Playing Hill, Tatupu, Hawthorne and Curry makes more sense than the DL by committee we have now.

The good: Since Vernon Gholston has now been confirmed to start at a DE position rather than DE/OLB, it looks like all of the Jets picks did indeed make sense. Ducasse is versatile and will fill most of the front's needs. I like the Jets for playoffs next year.

The bad: The Giants picked a high-risk DE with their first pick. Inside linebacker was a huge need which Reese didn't address until the fourth round. Weatherspoon would have been a better fit in Fewell's defense than McClain anyways. They made some good moves such as an eventual replacement for Feagles, and upgraded the interior with Linval. But unless they picked two raw DEs to replace Osi Umenyiora when he is eventually traded, I think they are over-crowding the roster.

The ugly: My poor Broncos. They filled plenty of needs with late picks, but made three big mistakes with their three first picks. They picked a drop-happy receiver who can't run routes at number 22. Then, at 25, they picked an overrated quarterback who looks more like a fullback than a quarterback (gets his shoulder ridiculously low, great after contact). Finally, they picked a round 4-5 prospect in the second round. That's too much of a reach for a need.
comments.subject: The good, the bad, and the ugly.

comments.article:
I'm thinking the Cleveland Browns had the best, or at least top 3, draft of all. Haden will be a beast at corner, Hardesty can start tomorrow, and Colt McCoy in round #3!? Holmgren and Heckart are showing their chops already.

Bite may be re-joining the Brownies' bark sooner than later.
comments.subject: Cleveland

comments.article:
I have to say I'm pretty disappointed. Mike Holmgren has been in this league for a long time, and having won a Super Bowl and appeared in the game thrice, he knows what it takes to go to the playoffs on a consistent basis.

Based on this draft, however, the Browns won't be getting anywhere near a postseason berth anytime soon.

The Joe Haden selection was great, but it was all downhill from there. T.J. Ward was a fifth-round prospect that Holmgren drafted in Round 2. Montario Hardesty, while having potential, wasn't a need in the slightest. The quarterback position was not addressed until the third round, when Holmgren took the spread-shotgun guy (Colt McCoy) despite passing on the West Coast pro-ready strong-armed quarterback (Jimmy Clausen).

I liked some of Cleveland's late-round picks, and I'm not going to forget that Sheldon Brown and Chris Gocong were acquired for some of them. However, the fact remains that this franchise is currently heading nowhere. To win consistently in the NFL, you need a franchise quarterback. Holmgren had Brett Favre in Green Bay and Matt Hasselbeck in Seattle. I don't know why he's suddenly ignoring the position.
comments.subject: Re: Cleveland
